results.abstract: New Year's Honors List drawn up by Prime Min Tony Blair's office includes names of John Gieve, Richard Bowker and Doug Smith, civil servants who have been associated with scandals or mismanagement; British call honors 'gongs' to denote long lists of awards, medals and knighthoods bestowed on those deemed worthy of such recognition (M)

headline.main: New Honors List in Britain Is Without Honor for Many

results.snippet: The inclusion of three civil servants whose names have been associated with scandals on Britain's New Year's Honors List has sparked a heated debate.
results.lead_paragraph: The British call the honors ''gongs,'' to denote the long lists of awards and medals and knighthoods bestowed on those deemed worthy of such recognition. But should they really be called ''gongs for gaffes?''

results.abstract: Seven astronauts of Discovery, space shuttle that NASA hopes to launch in spring of 2005 in first flight since Columbia disaster two years ago, say they are eager to return to orbit and resume nation's human spaceflight program (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Express Confidence in Safety of Planned Mission

results.snippet: The seven astronauts of the Discovery, the space shuttle that NASA hopes to launch this spring, said Friday that they were eager to return to orbit.
results.lead_paragraph: The seven astronauts of the Discovery, the space shuttle that NASA hopes to launch this spring in the first flight since the Columbia disaster two years ago, said Friday that they were eager to return to orbit and resume the nation's human spaceflight program. ''It's time for us to go fly,'' said the shuttle's commander, Col. Eileen M. Collins of the Air Force, in a news conference here, the first for the Discovery crew.

results.abstract: William Safire On Language column on words he calls 'tongue-tippers,' terms used in place of words on tip of speaker's tongue but just beyond linguistic reach; cites thingumabob, whichamahoosy and others (M)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-09-05: ON LANGUAGE

results.lead_paragraph: On the Dow Jones OpinionJournal Web site, Claudia Rosett -- the modern Inspector Javert of ''Les Mis√©rables'' on the oil-for-food trail of Jean Valjean -- reported on a news conference held by the U.N. secretary general: ''The contract that [Kofi] Annan referred to as 'this Cotecna one,' as if he weren't quite sure what whichamahoosy everyone was talking about.'' Pressed to reveal her source of the unfamiliar word, Rosett would say only, ''I borrowed it from an old family friend, who when she couldn't remember the name for something, would call it a whichamahoosy.'' I touched database with Google and can offer only one previous citation of that particular mouth-filler: a February 2002 use by a blogger who styles himself LoneRanger. It is related, I suspect, to hoosydingy, a word I have long used as a nonsense substitute when a specific term has slipped my mind. But even though I have tried all the variant spellings, I cannot find hoosydingy -- hoosiedinghy? -- in print anywhere. Closest use was by Kevin Paul Dupont in The Boston Globe early last year reporting about a hockey player's ''receiving off-site physical therapy for his aching whatchamacallit or whodingy.''

results.abstract: Margo Jefferson reviews exhibit White: Whiteness and Race in Contemporary Art at International Center of Photography; photos (M)

headline.main: Playing on Black and White: Racial Messages Through a Camera Lens

results.snippet: The excellent show at the International Center of Photography focuses on contemporary artists who deliberately examine racial myths and constructs.
results.lead_paragraph: What are we to expect when we walk into an exhibition titled ''White: Whiteness and Race in Contemporary Art''? First of all, a phrase like ''race in contemporary art'' almost always means that the race in question is nonwhite. As the show's curator, the art historian Maurice Berger writes in his introduction to this show, at the International Center of Photography: ''In mainstream American society and culture, whiteness remains an ever-present state of mind and body, a powerful norm so pervasive that it is rarely acknowledged or even named.'' In the 1990's, this awareness gave rise to an academic field called whiteness studies. The subject extends from history to culture, but the visual arts in particular seem ripe for analytic pickings. Now that the world is overpopulated by images, we have started to examine just how they shape our most basic modes of thought and feeling.

results.abstract: Boldface Names column on encounter with Tom Cruise and Lee Anne Devette, his sister and new publicist, at Critics' Choice Awards; Tim Robbins, Paul Giamatti and others also offer remarks (S)

byline.original: By Paula Schwartz; With David Jay Lasky in Los Angeles

results.lead_paragraph: He Ain't Tall; He's My Brother ''Which of your roles is closest to the real TOM CRUISE?'' a reporter (O.K., we admit it -- it was our very young reporter) asked the real Mr. Cruise on Monday night at the Critics' Choice Awards.

results.abstract: Endpaper essay by Arthur Mitchell, artistic director of Dance Theater of Harlem, explains his vision for school's 800 students, ages 3 to 24; photo (special section, Education Life) (M)
results.snippet: The financially troubled Dance Theater of Harlem shut its school in early fall, only to reopen last month through donations. The artistic director explains his vision here.
results.lead_paragraph: The financially troubled Dance Theater of Harlem shut its school in early fall, only to reopen last month with an infusion of $1.6 million in donations. Today, some 800 students, ages 3 to 24, study there with hopes of joining the troupe, or just for the joy of it. Arthur Mitchell, the artistic director, above, explains his vision: ''WHAT is the first art form? I say dance, because before the child is born, it kicks, and kicking is movement. It is how children express themselves. We use this idea in our after-school programs and in our work with public schoolteachers. We teach them how to use the arts and dance in teaching their subjects -- when you do a pass√©, what's that? That's a triangle! If you stand on one leg, take the other foot, bring it across your knee, that's a four! Newton? Who's Newton? Many of these children have never seen an apple tree. To explain gravity, I tell them to jump. You have to make things relevant.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students learn about the new findings from Saturn's moon, Titan, and why such information is important. They re-enact the press conference in which the findings are presented to the public, then individually reflect on how such findings are valuable to society.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students learn about the new findings from Saturn's moon, Titan, and why such information is important. They re-enact the press conference in which the findings are presented to the public, then individually reflect on how such...

byline.original: By PRISCILLA CHAN and JAVAID KHAN

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

results.abstract: Astronauts conducting busy spacewalk outside International Space Station discover clump of residue around three exterior vents that may be linked to persistent problems with outpost's oxygen system; details of other tasks conducted on spacewalk noted; photo (M)

headline.main: Astronauts at Space Station Conduct a Busy Spacewalk

results.snippet: Astronauts discovered a clump of residue around three exterior vents that may be linked to persistent problems with the outpost's oxygen system.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts conducting a busy spacewalk outside the International Space Station on Wednesday discovered a clump of residue around three exterior vents that may be linked to persistent problems with the outpost's oxygen system. Dr. Leroy Chiao, the station's American commander, and its flight engineer, Col. Salizhan S. Sharipov of the Russian Air Force, spent 5 hours and 28 minutes outside the station installing and removing equipment and inspecting the exterior.

results.abstract: Deborah Solomon interview with performance artist Laurie Anderson, whose new one-woman show The End of the Moon is based on her stint as artist in residence at NASA; Photo (m)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-30-05: QUESTIONS FOR LAURIE ANDERSON

results.snippet: The performance artist talks about spending a year at NASA, what she loves about space and what she hates about Broadway.
results.lead_paragraph: Q: Your new one-woman show, ''The End of the Moon,'' is based on your stint as an artist in residence at NASA. Why would a performance artist known for her iconoclasm want to visit mission control in Houston? As sad as I am about being in the United States these days, NASA is genuinely exciting. I keep thinking what it would be like to be a kid in this country. I think it would be really depressing, except for NASA.
